title: 1 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 5.

questions.question: To which city did the Philistines bring the ark of God after taking it from Ebenezer?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashdod
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:1 states that the Philistines brought the ark of God to Ashdod after taking it from Ebenezer.

questions.question: Where did the Philistines place the ark of God in Ashdod?
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of Dagon
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 5:2, the Philistines placed the ark in the house of Dagon.

questions.question: What happened to the statue of Dagon after the ark was placed by it in Ashdod?
options: It fell on its face before the ark
questions.correctAnswer: It fell on its face before the ark
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:3 states that Dagon was found fallen on his face before the ark of the LORD.

questions.question: What was found on the threshold the morning after Dagon fell?
options: The head and hands of Dagon
questions.correctAnswer: The head and hands of Dagon
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:4 describes that the head and both the palms of Dagon’s hands were cut off on the threshold.

questions.question: True or False: The priests of Dagon continued to tread on the threshold of Dagon's house in Ashdod.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:5 says neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone who comes into Dagon's house treads on the threshold to this day.

questions.question: What affliction did the LORD bring upon the people of Ashdod and its coasts?
questions.correctAnswer: Emerods
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 5:6, the LORD smote the people of Ashdod with emerods.

questions.question: Why did the men of Ashdod say the ark of the God of Israel could not remain with them?
options: Because the LORD’s hand was sore upon them
Because it was a burden to carry
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD’s hand was sore upon them
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:7 shows the men of Ashdod said the ark shall not abide with them because the LORD’s hand was sore upon them and Dagon.

questions.question: To which city did the Philistines first carry the ark after Ashdod?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:8 states they carried the ark about to Gath after Ashdod.

questions.question: What happened to the people of Gath after the ark was brought there?
questions.correctAnswer: They were smitten with emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:9 reports that the LORD smote the people of Gath with emerods and destruction.

questions.question: True or False: The Ekronites welcomed the ark of the God of Israel without fear.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:10 says the Ekronites cried out fearing the ark would slay them and their people.

questions.question: What did the lords of the Philistines decide to do with the ark of the God of Israel in Ekron?
options: Send it away to its own place
questions.correctAnswer: Send it away to its own place
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:11 records that the lords of the Philistines said to send the ark away to its own place to avoid destruction.

questions.question: What happened to those who did not die from the affliction in the city where the ark was kept?
questions.correctAnswer: They were smitten with emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:12 states that those who did not die were smitten with emerods.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The Philistines took the ark of God, and brought it from ______ unto Ashdod.
questions.correctAnswer: Ebenezer
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:1 states the ark was taken from Ebenezer to Ashdod.

questions.question: True or False: After the ark was placed by Dagon, the statue’s head and hands were found intact the next day.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:4 explains that Dagon’s head and both hands were cut off on the threshold.

questions.question: Who did the men of Ashdod gather to ask what to do with the ark?
options: All the lords of the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: All the lords of the Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:8 shows they gathered all the lords of the Philistines to decide what to do with the ark.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during difficult circumstances. Based on 1 Samuel 5, what biblical truth would you share about God's power?
options: God is sovereign and can humble false gods before Him
God is distant and does not intervene in human affairs
God only works through miracles in the New Testament
God requires us to rely on human strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign and can humble false gods before Him
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:2-4 shows how the God of Israel humbled the Philistine god Dagon by causing him to fall and lose his head and hands, demonstrating God's supreme power over idols.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 5 teach about the consequences of not honoring the true God?
options: Those who reject God face judgment and suffering
God ignores those who dishonor Him
Only the priests are accountable for honoring God
Punishment comes only in the afterlife
questions.correctAnswer: Those who reject God face judgment and suffering
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 9, and 12 describe how the Philistines suffered from painful emerods and destruction as a consequence of keeping the ark and dishonoring the LORD, illustrating practical consequences of rejecting God.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged by trials and asks how to respond with humility. What insight does 1 Samuel 5 provide?
options: Humility before God allows His power to be shown
Pride is necessary to overcome trials
Self-reliance is the key to success
questions.correctAnswer: Humility before God allows His power to be shown
questions.explanation: The repeated humbling of Dagon (verses 3-4) demonstrates that God's power is revealed when people humble themselves before Him and acknowledge His sovereignty.

questions.question: What does the reaction of the men of Ashdod to the ark teach about obedience and reverence to God?
options: They recognized God's hand and sought to remove the ark
They ignored the signs and kept the ark
They worshiped the ark as a god
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized God's hand and sought to remove the ark
questions.explanation: Verse 7 reveals that the men of Ashdod acknowledged God's power and the harm His presence caused them, leading them to seek the ark's removal to avoid further judgment.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to maintain integrity under pressure. How does the story of the Philistines with the ark teach about respecting God's holiness?
options: Disrespecting God's holiness brings severe consequences
God's holiness is not relevant to daily life
Only priests need to respect God's holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Disrespecting God's holiness brings severe consequences
questions.explanation: The consequences faced by the Philistines for placing the ark in Dagon’s temple and their failure to honor God properly (verses 2-6, 11-12) teach the importance of reverence and obedience in all aspects of life.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 5 encourage believers to trust God’s timing and methods in delivering them?
options: God’s deliverance may come through unexpected trials
God always delivers immediately and visibly
Believers should force God’s hand with their plans
Deliverance depends on human power only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s deliverance may come through unexpected trials
questions.explanation: The Philistines suffered greatly because of the ark's presence (verses 6-10), but this shows that God's intervention can come in ways that test faith and demonstrate His power beyond human expectations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment during trials. What lesson does 1 Samuel 5 give about being content in God’s sovereignty?
options: Contentment comes from trusting God despite hardships
God’s sovereignty is limited by circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment comes from trusting God despite hardships
questions.explanation: The Philistines’ suffering in 1 Samuel 5 illustrates that God’s hand is heavy even in trials, but trusting Him leads to spiritual growth and recognition of His authority (verses 6-8).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 5, the Philistines willingly kept the ark of God in their cities despite the afflictions they suffered.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 7-11 show that the Philistines repeatedly moved the ark from city to city because they feared the destruction it brought, indicating they did not willingly keep it despite afflictions.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 5 teach about the importance of seeking counsel in difficult situations?
options: The Philistines gathered their lords to decide what to do with the ark
Individuals should always act without consulting others
God does not want us to seek advice
Counsel is only necessary for kings
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines gathered their lords to decide what to do with the ark
questions.explanation: Verse 8 demonstrates that the Philistines sought collective counsel when faced with a challenging problem, illustrating the biblical principle of seeking wise counsel in difficulty.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 5, what does the removal of Dagon’s head and hands symbolize about human power compared to God’s power?
options: Human power is powerless before God’s supreme authority
Human power is equal to God’s power
Human power can defeat God’s power
God’s power is limited by idols
questions.correctAnswer: Human power is powerless before God’s supreme authority
questions.explanation: The mutilation of Dagon, the Philistine god, in verses 3-4 symbolizes the futility of human or idol power when confronted with the living God of Israel.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their faith in the workplace. What principle from 1 Samuel 5 would you share about standing firm in faith?
options: Trusting God’s power protects us even in opposition
Faith is only for church, not work
Human strength is enough to overcome challenges
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s power protects us even in opposition
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s power in protecting His holiness even when His ark was among hostile Philistines, encouraging believers to stand firm in faith despite opposition (verses 6-12).

questions.question: True or False: The priests of Dagon and those entering Dagon's house continued to walk on the threshold after the defilement described in 1 Samuel 5.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone entering Dagon’s house would tread on the threshold after the head and hands of Dagon were cut off, showing reverence or fear.

questions.question: A believer is learning about stewardship and service in the church. How does 1 Samuel 5 illustrate the importance of honoring God's presence in fellowship?
options: God’s presence brings blessing when honored, and judgment if disrespected
God’s presence is irrelevant in church life
Only material offerings matter in service
God accepts any kind of worship without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence brings blessing when honored, and judgment if disrespected
questions.explanation: The Philistines’ experience with the ark in their cities shows that God’s presence demands respect, and failing to honor Him results in judgment (verses 2-12).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The Philistines experienced __________ in their secret parts as a result of keeping the ark of the God of Israel among them.
questions.correctAnswer: emerods
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 9, and 12 specify that the Philistines were struck with emerods, a painful affliction, as a direct consequence of the ark's presence.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 5 teach about sharing the truth of God’s power with others?
options: God’s power will be evident and undeniable to witnesses
God’s power should be hidden from others
Only priests can share about God’s power
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power will be evident and undeniable to witnesses
questions.explanation: The widespread suffering of the Philistines and their recognition of God's hand (verses 7, 11) show that God’s power and truth become clear to all who observe His actions.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by repeated setbacks. Based on 1 Samuel 5, what biblical virtue should they cultivate?
options: Perseverance in trusting God despite trials
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance in trusting God despite trials
questions.explanation: The Philistines’ repeated attempts to rid themselves of the ark and the ongoing consequences demonstrate the need for perseverance and trust in God's purposes even when trials continue (verses 7-12).

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 5.

questions.question: What was the initial destination of the Ark of God after the Philistines captured it?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashdod
questions.explanation: The Philistines took the ark from Ebenezer to Ashdod, as stated in 1 Samuel 5:1.

questions.question: In what location was the Ark placed in Ashdod?
questions.correctAnswer: House of Dagon
questions.explanation: The ark was brought into the house of Dagon and set by Dagon, according to 1 Samuel 5:2.

questions.question: What happened to the statue of Dagon the morning after the ark was placed beside it?
options: It was found fallen on its face before the ark
questions.correctAnswer: It was found fallen on its face before the ark
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:3 describes that Dagon was fallen upon his face to the earth before the ark of the LORD.

questions.question: What specific damage was observed on the statue of Dagon the second morning?
options: Its head and palms of hands were cut off
questions.correctAnswer: Its head and palms of hands were cut off
questions.explanation: Verse 1 Samuel 5:4 states that the head and both palms of Dagon's hands were cut off on the threshold.

questions.question: True or False: The priests of Dagon and visitors continued to tread on Dagon's threshold in Ashdod after these events.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:5 indicates that neither priests nor visitors tread on Dagon’s threshold in Ashdod to that day.

questions.question: What affliction did the LORD inflict on the people of Ashdod as a result of the ark's presence?
questions.correctAnswer: Emerods (tumors)
questions.explanation: The LORD smote them with emerods, which are tumors, as described in 1 Samuel 5:6.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the men of Ashdod to the affliction caused by the ark?
options: They decided the ark should not stay with them
They tried to destroy the ark
questions.correctAnswer: They decided the ark should not stay with them
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 5:7, the men of Ashdod said the ark shall not abide with them because God's hand was sore upon them.

questions.question: To which city was the ark sent after Ashdod?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: The ark was carried to Gath as per the lords' advice in 1 Samuel 5:8.

questions.question: What happened to the city of Gath after the ark was brought there?
options: Faced great destruction and affliction with emerods
questions.correctAnswer: Faced great destruction and affliction with emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:9 records that the hand of the LORD was against Gath with great destruction and emerods.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Ekronites upon the ark's arrival in their city?
options: They cried out fearing death and destruction
They sought to keep it permanently
questions.correctAnswer: They cried out fearing death and destruction
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 5:10, the Ekronites cried out, fearing the ark would slay them and their people.

questions.question: What action did the Philistine lords decide upon in response to the ark’s deadly impact?
options: To keep the ark in Ekron
To send the ark back to Israel
To build a temple for the ark
questions.correctAnswer: To send the ark back to Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:11 shows that the lords said to send the ark away to its own place to stop the destruction.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The men who did not die were smitten with ________, and the city’s cry went up to heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:12 states that those who were not killed were smitten with emerods, and the city's cry went up to heaven.

questions.question: Which theme in 1 Samuel 5 foreshadows the future supremacy of Yahweh over false gods?
options: The building of a new temple
The peace between Philistines and Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Dagon’s statue
questions.explanation: The repeated falling and damage to Dagon’s statue (1 Samuel 5:3-4) symbolizes Yahweh’s superiority over false gods, a theme developed throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does the narrative of the Ark in 1 Samuel 5 relate to the broader biblical motif of God's holiness and the consequences of disrespecting it?
options: It shows that God is indifferent
It illustrates severe judgment on those who treat the sacred irreverently
It suggests God accepts any treatment of the Ark
It indicates the Ark is powerless
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates severe judgment on those who treat the sacred irreverently
questions.explanation: The afflictions on the Philistines for mishandling the Ark (1 Samuel 5) echo the biblical theme that God’s holiness demands reverence and disobedience brings judgment.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew word 'emerods' used in this chapter most likely refer to in the ancient medical context?
questions.correctAnswer: Hemorrhoids or painful tumors
questions.explanation: The term 'emerods' refers to swellings or tumors, possibly hemorrhoids, as an affliction sent by God (1 Samuel 5:6,9,12).

questions.question: True or False: The narrative of 1 Samuel 5 demonstrates the Philistines’ recognition of Yahweh’s power over their god Dagon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The Philistines acknowledged Yahweh’s power as they feared the ark and the destruction it brought, showing recognition of His supremacy over Dagon (1 Samuel 5:7).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What did the Philistines do with the ark of God after capturing it from Ebenezer?
options: Brought it into the house of Dagon in Ashdod
Sent it back immediately to Israel
Destroyed it as a symbol of Israel's defeat
Placed it in the temple of Baal in Gath
questions.correctAnswer: Brought it into the house of Dagon in Ashdod
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:1-2 records that the Philistines took the ark from Ebenezer to Ashdod and placed it in the house of Dagon. This act shows their attempt to demonstrate the superiority of their god over Israel's God, but it ironically reveals God's sovereignty. This is consistent with God's supremacy seen in Exodus 12:12, where God shows His power over Egyptian gods, and in Colossians 2:15 where Christ disarmed principalities and powers.

questions.question: What happened to the statue of Dagon when the Philistines placed the ark beside it?
options: It fell on its face before the ark of the LORD
It caught fire and was consumed
It was stolen by the Israelites during the night
questions.correctAnswer: It fell on its face before the ark of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:3 describes that the statue of Dagon fell on its face before the ark, indicating the impotence of false gods before the living God. This echoes the biblical theme of God's superiority over idols seen in Isaiah 46:1-2 and Psalm 115:4-8, affirming the Lord's divine authority and power.

questions.question: What was the condition of Dagon's statue the second morning after the ark was placed beside it?
options: The head and both palms were cut off, leaving only a stump
It was restored to its original position without damage
It was covered with a veil by the priests
questions.correctAnswer: The head and both palms were cut off, leaving only a stump
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:4 records the symbolic humiliation of Dagon as its head and hands were severed, demonstrating God's judgment against idolatry. This aligns with biblical motifs of divine judgment against false gods, such as in Habakkuk 2:18-20 and Jeremiah 10:3-5, emphasizing God's holiness and justice.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 5, what did the priests of Dagon and others avoid doing because of what happened to the statue?
options: Treading on the threshold of Dagon's house
Entering the house of Dagon altogether
Speaking the name of Dagon aloud
questions.correctAnswer: Treading on the threshold of Dagon's house
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:5 states that neither the priests nor anyone who enters Dagon's house treads on the threshold because of the statue's mutilation. This shows reverence mixed with fear due to divine judgment, reflecting the biblical principle of holy reverence found in Exodus 3:5 and Hebrews 12:28.

questions.question: What calamity did the LORD bring upon the people of Ashdod and its surrounding areas?
options: He sent a famine upon them
He brought a plague of locusts
questions.correctAnswer: He smote them with emerods (tumors)
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 5:6, the LORD’s hand was heavy upon Ashdod, smiting them with emerods, a painful affliction. This reflects God's sovereign power over nations and judgment on those who oppose Him, similar to the plagues in Egypt (Exodus 9:8-12) and the afflictions upon those who reject God’s covenant (Deuteronomy 28:27-29).

questions.question: Why did the men of Ashdod decide the ark of Israel should not stay with them?
options: Because God's hand was sore upon them and upon Dagon their god
Because they feared an Israeli attack
Because the ark was considered cursed by their priests
Because they wanted to return it to Israel as a peace offering
questions.correctAnswer: Because God's hand was sore upon them and upon Dagon their god
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:7 reveals that the men of Ashdod acknowledged the severity of God's judgment and decided the ark could not stay because of the heavy hand of God upon them and their god Dagon. This recognition of divine power over idols is consistent with biblical teaching in Jeremiah 10:11 and Acts 19:26.

questions.question: Where did the Philistines decide to carry the ark after Ashdod?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:8 states that after consulting, the Philistines moved the ark to Gath. This movement shows their attempt to contain or control the power of Israel’s God, reflecting the biblical narrative of God's sovereignty over nations (Psalm 22:28) and the futility of human efforts to manipulate divine power.

questions.question: What was the effect of the ark's presence on the city of Gath?
options: Great destruction and men smitten with emerods
The city prospered and received blessings
The priests of Dagon welcomed the ark
questions.correctAnswer: Great destruction and men smitten with emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:9 shows that the LORD’s hand caused severe destruction in Gath, striking both small and great with emerods. This divine judgment illustrates God's holiness and justice, similar to the judgments against sinners in Exodus 12 and the plagues in Egypt (Exodus 11:1-10), emphasizing that God's presence demands reverence.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Ekronites when the ark arrived in their city?
options: They cried out fearing the ark would slay them
They sought to worship the God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They cried out fearing the ark would slay them
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:10 reports the Ekronites’ fear that the ark would bring death upon them, indicating awareness of God's power and judgment. This reflects the biblical principle of fearing God’s holiness, as in Isaiah 8:13 and Hebrews 12:29, emphasizing that God's presence brings both awe and fear.

questions.question: What did the lords of the Philistines decide to do with the ark after seeing the destruction it caused in Ekron?
options: Send it away back to its own place
Keep it in Ekron under guard
Offer sacrifices to the God of Israel
Hide it in a secret place within Philistia
questions.correctAnswer: Send it away back to its own place
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:11 explains that the Philistine lords decided to send the ark back to Israel to stop the deadly destruction caused by God's hand. This decision shows acknowledgment of God's authority and aligns with the biblical theme of God's vindication of His holiness as seen in Exodus 33:15-16 and Psalm 68:1.

questions.question: What happened to the men who did not die from the emerods in the cities where the ark was kept?
options: They were taken captive by Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: They were smitten with emerods
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 5:12 states that those who did not die were still afflicted with emerods, showing the comprehensive nature of God's judgment. This reflects the biblical teaching of God's righteous judgment on sin, as in Romans 1:18 and Hebrews 10:31, emphasizing the holiness and justice of God.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s power is demonstrated by the events of 1 Samuel 5?
options: God is sovereign over all nations and their gods
God is limited to Israel’s territory
God’s power is equal to other gods
God requires human mediation to act
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign over all nations and their gods
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s power over the Philistines, their gods, and cities, demonstrating His universal sovereignty (1 Samuel 5:1-12). This is consistent with scriptures such as Psalm 97:9, Isaiah 45:5-7, and Colossians 1:16-17, affirming God’s supreme authority over all creation.

questions.question: How does the judgment on the statue of Dagon relate to the biblical doctrine of idolatry?
options: It demonstrates that idols are powerless before the living God
It shows idols have independent power
It implies idols should be worshiped alongside God
It suggests idols can protect people from God’s judgment
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates that idols are powerless before the living God
questions.explanation: The statue’s fall and mutilation (1 Samuel 5:3-4) symbolize God’s judgment on idolatry, affirming that idols are lifeless and ineffective, consistent with Isaiah 44:9-20 and 1 Corinthians 8:4-6, reinforcing monotheism and God’s uniqueness.

questions.question: What does the heavy hand of the LORD upon the Philistines illustrate about His character?
options: His holiness and justice against sin
questions.correctAnswer: His holiness and justice against sin
questions.explanation: The affliction of the Philistines (1 Samuel 5:6) reveals God's holy justice punishing defiance and irreverence, consistent with Habakkuk 1:13, Romans 1:18, and Revelation 15:4, demonstrating that God is righteous and must judge sin.

questions.question: What eschatological principle can be drawn from the Philistines’ experience with the ark in 1 Samuel 5?
options: God’s judgment is inevitable for those who reject Him
All nations will ultimately worship idols
God’s power is limited in the last days
The ark brings prosperity to whoever possesses it
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is inevitable for those who reject Him
questions.explanation: The Philistines’ rejection and destruction (1 Samuel 5:7-12) foreshadow the final judgment themes in Revelation 20:11-15 and Matthew 25:31-46, highlighting that God's righteous judgment will come upon all who reject Him, affirming God's justice and sovereignty throughout history.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 5 illustrate the holiness of God and the danger of approaching Him irreverently?
options: By showing that the presence of the ark caused painful afflictions and death
By showing that the ark was powerless outside Israel
By showing that the Philistines could worship God successfully
By showing that God allowed the idols to remain unpunished
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that the presence of the ark caused painful afflictions and death
questions.explanation: The chapter demonstrates that God's presence is holy and dangerous to those who approach Him irreverently, as seen in the afflictions upon the Philistines (1 Samuel 5:6-12). This aligns with Exodus 19:12-13, Leviticus 10:1-2, and Hebrews 12:29, emphasizing reverence before God.
